bibl.title: Chin Hing v. United States of America. Commission

msIdentifier.repository: National Archives and Records Administration, Seattle Branch, Washington
msIdentifier.collection: RG 21 US District Court Western Division of Washington, Seattle

div1.p: In the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington
The President of the United States of America, To Thomas G. Lewish, Attorney and Notary Public, Commercial Bank Building, Washington, D.C.

Greeting: Know Ye, The we, in confidence of your prudence and fidelity, have appointed you Commissioner and by these present do give you full power and authority diligently to examine uupon corporal oath or affirmation, before you to be taken, and upon the interrogatories and cross interrogatories hereunto annexed of Louis F. Post, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Labor, Washington, D.C. Corry M. Stadden, Attorney of Washington, D.C. as witnesses on the part of the Petitioner in a certain cause now pending undetermined in the District Court of the United States of the Ninth Judicial Circuit in and for the Western District of Washington, wherein Ching Hing is Petitioner and United States Government and Henry M. White as Respondents;

And we do further empower you Thomas G. Lewis, to examine on the same behalf and in like manner, any other person or persons who may be produced as witnesses before you; and we do hereby require you Thomas G. Lewis, before whom such testimony may be taken, to reduce the same to writing, and to close it up under your hand and seal directed to Frank L. Crosby, Clerk of the District Court of the United States for the Western District of Washington, at the City of Seattle, as soon as may be convenient after the execution of this commission; and that you return the same when executed, as above directed, with the title of the cause endorsed on the envelope of the commission.

Witness, the Honorable Jeremiah Neterer, Judge of said Court, this 20th day of October, in the year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and fourteen and of our independence the one hundred and thirty-ninth.
